thread.title_full: Mid Drift Movement wants to reclaim body-after-baby conversation - Chicago Tribune

author: Heidi Stevens
title: Mid Drift Movement wants to reclaim body-after-baby conversation - Chicago Tribune
text:
If Angie Sonrode has her way, moms will behold their post-baby bodies with reverence and awe.
Not easy in a culture that views stretch marks with shock and awe.
Sonrode, a Minnesota-based parent educator, La Leche League leader, yoga instructor and mother of four, has launched the Mid Drift Movement (tag line: "Exposing the soft underbelly of motherhood") to help reshape our standards of beauty, particularly as they apply to mothers' bodies.
"Instead of honoring the new road map on their body, which they've earned," Sonrode told me, "moms are stuck focusing on, 'What are people going to think about my body?'"
The centerpiece of the movement is a documentary that Sonrode and her husband, Mike, are filming, exploring America's obsession with "body after baby" and looking at how other countries and cultures perceive postpartum bodies.
"Mid Drift aims to start a fresh conversation about the realities of motherhood, the truth about the postpartum body, and the challenges faced by women and their partners as they encounter society's unfair expectations," Sonrode writes on the documentary's fundraising site.
It's a conversation that's already taking place in big and small ways. The Fourth Trimester Bodies Project photographs mothers and documents their narratives of joy, grief and transition. The Honest Body Project does similar work, as does the powerful A Beautiful Body Project .
Sonrode views such groups as allies, and is reaching out to them to join forces.
"We're not reinventing the wheel," she said. "We are taking this energy that's built up and saying, 'Let's change the perception together.' We're not saying, 'Hey, let's rise to the top.' We're saying, 'Hey, join us.'"
The more the mightier, I say, especially when you're battling powerful, entrenched forces like the multimillion-dollar retail and beauty industries, which are egged on by magazines — of the celebrity gossip and fashion variety — that hold up endless examples of toned, taut, tiny post-baby bodies for women to aspire to.
"I have so many dreams for this movement," Sonrode told me. "If we make even one woman feel better about herself, mission accomplished. But what I really want to do is shift the conversation about 'body after baby' to ask, 'Why? Why are we focused on getting our bodies back to the way they used to be?'
"Hopefully, we can encourage and empower not just mothers, but others to look at postpartum bodies as something women have earned," she continued. "I do think we could see the pendulum swing. It's going to be a slow swing, but if enough of us are willing to say, 'This is what I look like under my clothes,' I think we can make a difference."
